title: Episode 355 - Coordinating Provers with Norbert from ZkCloud

rawLines.text: [Music]
welcome to Zero Knowledge I'm your host
Anna Rose In this podcast we will be
exploring the latest in zero knowledge
research and the decentralized web as
well as new paradigms that promise to
change the way we interact and transact
online
[Music]
This week I chat with Norbert head of
product at ZK Cloud which was previously
Galot We dive back into the topic of
prover networks mapping out the
different actors in the ZK proving
supply chain We discussed the different
ways in which teams building prover
marketplaces build the economics of
these systems and the trade-offs each of
these models offer We then discussed the
ZK cloud system and what he thinks
large-scale industrial-grade proving
will look like in the future Now before
we kick off I do want to just let you
know about the ZK Summit ZK Summit 13 is
coming up It's happening on May 12th in
Toronto If you've never been to a ZK
Summit I definitely recommend checking
it out This is the spot to find out
about the latest research the newest
applications to find out who are the
most important players in ZK today It's
also a wonderful way to get to know sort
of the larger ZK community The
application to attend is now open Links
as always are in the show notes and I
hope to see you there Now Tanya will
share a little bit about this week's
[Music]
sponsor ZK is finally easy with Noir the
fastest growing zero knowledge
programming language Built privacy
preserving apps without any ZK
experience Apps today all look alike
especially across chains Noir gives you
simple privacy tools to build something
new Noir is rustbased backend agnostic
and already used by leading ecosystems
like Starkware World and Aptos Aztec
Labs is running a 4-week program Noir
Hack with 200K in funding and grants
You'll get hands-on support from a
dedicated team of 10 Devrils weekly deep
dives partner workshops and a demo day
where you'll pitch to judges from Bass
A16Z Crypto IOSG Ventures and Paradigm
Applications close soon Sign up now at
noirhack.com That's noirhack.com N oi
rhk.com And now here's our
[Music]
episode Today I'm here with Norbert head
of product at ZK Cloud which was
previously called Galot Welcome to the
show Norbert Hi Anna Thank you very much
for having me I'm excited to have you on
So we've actually been in touch quite
often because ZKV my other project has
been working with ZK Cloud ZKV is right
now an operator both a validator
improver on the permissioned early
network firestarter and ZK cloud Cohen
from my team I know speaks to you quite
regularly but he is the one doing most
of the work I think you'll hear from
this interview I still have a lot to
learn I'm so glad that you're on the
show to share with us a little bit like
the state of prover networks how they've
evolved over time what you guys are
doing specifically Yeah I'm looking
forward to it Thanks a lot Actually
we're very happy to be working with you
guys Yes I've mostly been in touch with
Cohen because as you mentioned um you
are one of the prover node operators on
our scalable permission network firest
starter But then as we get closer to the
mainet launch and we started uh
validator on boarding I think ZKV is
also participating there So super happy
to be working with you guys in different
fronts Yeah Very cool Norbert I think
you and I met actually in KCO You had
joined uh on behalf of what was at the
time the Galot team as a sponsor We did
the ZK hack KCO event And I just I just
really remember this t-shirt that you
printed which had this basically Gaylord
from the ZK hack team had done a bunch
of stickers and one of them had this
dragon and you managed to grab it and
print it and it's quite it's quite a
stunning shirt I've seen it a few times
around since then Yeah I mean people
have been coming up to me and uh asking
me about that shirt whether we do have
some you know a couple of samples that
could be distributed because it's it's
been really popular And I also hear
funny thing some of those shirts are
still walking around in Krakco on random
people because the local people love it
so much I don't know how it landed there
Yeah Uh but it's it's a funny story Nice
So what I want to do with today's
episode is really look at prover
networks I think we have covered this
previously on the show and so we'll dig
up any old episodes where we kind of
introduced the concept but I think it's
really exciting to have you on to do a
bit of a snapshot of like where we're at
today with prover networks We hear a lot
about a lot of teams that are launching
prover networks or partnering with
prover networks and I think trying to
understand what they are how they've
evolved how different teams are kind of
interacting with them will be really
helpful So let's start by going way back
in time to the beginning of prover
networks aka 3 years ago four years ago
I don't think it's that long ago
actually somewhere around there Yeah
2021 possibly So yeah I want to talk to
you a bit about like what were those
early prover networks or prover
marketplaces as they were called back
then Yeah so to be honest with you I was
uh just coming to the blockchain space
back then Uh so I may have a little
smaller grasp on on that era of proving
basically But I do know that um
basically the first ones were Mina's
marketplace which they used to call
snark marketplace
maybe even today And then uh I think
actually nil was also starting off
creating a proof market which then uh
and then they pivoted to building an L2
based on ZK sharding but that's a
different story regarding the the snark
marketplace what I remember um having
heard and having read is that um so it
was mainly generating proofs for the
Mina blockchain Yeah And um what was
very interesting and very eye opening
also for us particularly is that um some
entities started offering proofs in that
marketplace um for free and it just
basically killed the competition killed
economics basically it killed the
marketplace and obviously there are ways
to come around that Um however it was a
a really important moment where and I
think architecturally it's it's a very
important topic how you want to
distribute proving because auctions have
their advantages but also as we've seen
with this marketplace they are gameable
and there can be situations where uh
large entities could could easily gain
monopoly On the other hand other
approaches may have their own um
benefits and advantages and happy to
dive deeper uh on that later on Cool
Yeah at ZKV actually also ran I guess it
was approver on the snark marketplace Um
but I remember like we were
participating early on but I think
eventually like you just described first
I think there wasn't enough demand for
proofs because it was just for the
blockchain itself not for applications
living on the blockchain yet later they
released the the language and then you
could create applications and then you
needed a lot more proofs so it started
to make more sense but back then it was
just the recursive proof that like kind
of powers the Mina blockchain
being created and it just wasn't enough
demand and then like you said like
someone you know people came in with
zero fees zero cost and it sort of tanks
the marketplace I would mention one
other team that I believe like that I
think has a prover network of some kind
which is IO because they're running
hardware provers as part of their
offering as well but as far as I know
they're only proving the Alo network Y I
think it was last year where we started
to hear maybe maybe the year before
actually where we started to hear this
sort of story of of prover networks
prover marketplaces coming back where
teams were talking also about like
decentralized prover networks where
you'd have multiple provers potentially
proving multiple L2s or anyone who would
need these sort of proof requesters
people who needed ZKPs And so it stopped
being sort of this ver this vertical
integration where it was often like a
blockchain plus their own prover network
and more like this prover network like
true network as a as a service proving
to me multiple parties Tell me a little
bit about because I think galot zk cloud
comes from that era Exactly So tell me a
little bit about what the thinking was
there That's a very interesting era I
think in it was in summer 2023
Um
I was in uh in Paris ECC and actually it
was talk rule talking about the
different ways to approach proving for
example for an L2 So currently it's it's
a well-known fact that basically the
largest proof demand is coming from
ZKL2s
um validity rollups mainly and there's
been quite some talk about whether they
should build an enshrined prover network
meaning an in protocol prover network
and bring that network entity beside the
sequencer into the protocol bake it in
and uh progress that way or go with a
third party proof provider who could
optimize for proving but then you know
the thing is that it's the go to market
is much easier with a third party
network because you don't need to build
everything yourself On the other hand
it's very important to ensure that
whoever you outsource your proving to
does not introduce unnecessary or
unhealthy dependencies or maybe even you
know you build a nicely decentralized
validator set but then you have a
centralized prover who is you know
introducing trade-offs to your network
that you've built I mean this is not the
situation with the current L2s because
most of them are running in a
centralized fashion and exploring
they're running their own right Yeah Um
and and like they do uh sequencing
except for Tao obviously because uh
that's a based roll out but uh most of
the L2s are doing both sequencing and
proving for themselves There are some um
that are um already actively exploring
decentralization of sequencing
governance proving etc etc and also some
others like Aztec for example who want
to go decentralized from day one Yeah So
both on their test net and um on their
main net and I think also ZKV has been
um involved in sequencing and and
proving of uh the Aztec test net Yep
That phenomenon of rollups I mean it's
true now nowadays there are these
rollups that are hopefully going to
launch with that decentralized but when
they first launched all of them or most
of them were quite centralized So
centralized sequencer centralized prover
I always wondered where do those
actually happen like where like you talk
about it being centralized but is it
like AWS is it like hardware do they
have distributed provers at least or
distributed sequencers but all
controlled by them do you know this i
mean I do have some information about
different teams Most of them were
basically renting large clusters from
Google or or Amazon Okay So it was a
very kind of like one of the approaches
uh dominant there And then um I do know
of some teams who had private
engagements with u GPU farms or uh you
know data center operators and um
renting compute from a couple of
different places But what's very
important I think and that's already
leading or pointing towards the dynamics
changing is that when you rent your own
machines and you run your own proving
you need to rent machines to cover your
redundancy or else you will have you
know an extended uh and prolonged
finality in times of transaction peaks
etc etc So it's very interesting to see
the different approaches but it's also
very interesting to see that um
basically over time the industry started
leaning toward third party proving and
not anymore thinking about building
their own in protocol approver networks
Oh and then third party proving
obviously has a couple of advantages
that uh are are worth mentioning It's
the paper proof model versus you know
you rent your servers and they are
sitting idle if there is no proof to be
generated or or if transaction volume
are low that's burning a lot of uh
runway for the different teams So
basically the paper proof models that
are available through prover
marketplaces or prover networks or even
some um centralized proof providers out
there um they come in very handy What I
would add on top is that and this may
even be a larger chunk of the cost but
saving the idle time for all these teams
may actually be a larger saving than
just making proving the cost per proof
cheaper So that's an interesting dynamic
there
Interesting I feel like we should name
some of the actors sort of the roles
that exist in this I'm going to call it
supply chain or chain of actors that are
creating proofs We can use maybe the L2
as an example So we've mentioned this
like sequencer and prover In this case
the way that I think this is often
described in the prover network context
is the L2 is a proof requesttor It needs
proofs In the case that we just
described where that L2 is running its
own provers it is also the proof
provider or the
prover networks though kind of live in
between that right so you have proof
requesters could be an L2 could be
something else and then you have this
prover network which can create proofs
for the proof requester But they're
often as as I understand it almost like
bringing in these prover machines from
different places in order to satisfy Is
that how you would define a prover
network yes I think that's that's more
or less what a proven network is like
where they source the compute capacity
from That may differ though uh pretty
significantly because in that sense I'
I'd rather maybe uh call the bucket
proof providers or like proving services
Okay And as you said so there is the
proof requesttor Um there is a proving
service which needs to source compute
from somewhere and then uh the supply
chain progresses with the verifier uh
and the settlement of the uh of the
proof itself But regarding proof
networks and and marketplaces I mean the
marketplace itself already hints at
anyone who has hardware either through
renting or having their own clusters on
prem they could come in they could
submit bids in the marketplace to win
the right for different proving jobs But
then in a prover network that's a little
bit different I think because um and
it's particularly because the prover
networks may have different workload
allocation mechanisms And what I mean by
that is a prover network can be
decentralized and permissionless
allowing anyone to come in and
contribute compute and then still use an
auction mechanism to win proving jobs
and to distribute the different jobs to
um certain providers um certain node
operators in the network However with
for example Gavlot and Zigg cloud we
actually build our network in a way that
we randomly assign proving workloads to
proven node operators So in that sense
it's it's a permissionless network that
we are building Anyone can join who
meets the minimum hardware requirements
and then the randomness based selection
ensures neutrality minimizes
centralization risks etc etc what's
there and what's important I think for
all these L2s even though most of them
are running in a centralized fashion now
and exploring the way to decentralized
both sequencing and the proving on the
other hand it's going to be a very
important decision I'd say what kind of
proof provider they select because the
architectures of those providers may
come with significant tradeoffs in
certain cases the proof provider the way
you've defined behind it This could be a
prover network Could be also a direct
prover right like proof provider is
anyone who's creating proofs or proofs
are being generated somehow by this
entity Yes But when we go to the prover
network like what do you call the
provers that feed the just the prover
network i usually call them prover node
operators Okay Okay They are the ones
with the actual hardware plugging into
the prover network um and contributing
the compute Got it The prover node
operators like I have heard and I think
maybe we're far off from this but I've
heard like the proposition that one day
maybe you anyone can be a prover node
operator You could prove from your phone
You could prove from your laptop It
seems like and also because we're in it
we're experimenting with this as well So
right now it seems like we're pretty far
off from that Like the prover node
operators tend to need to actually have
pretty significant hardware and like
you're you're not running this on sort
of like a random laptop at this point
Yeah So I think that there are different
approaches and it's absolutely possible
that there will be certain teams who
will take the approach and allow any
type of consumer grade hardware even you
know browser based proving or mobile
phones to come in and contribute compute
The approach for example we've taken
with ZK cloud is that uh we have to have
a a certain minimum hardware requirement
to be met because that's part of our
optimization strategy uh from different
angles Since we use randomness to
distribute workloads in our network we
need to ensure that um everybody has a
uniform minimum capacity you know if you
use a let's say um a consumer grade
laptop and I have a huge cluster of you
know we cannot be in the same random
selection in that sense so it's
important for us to have some uniform uh
capacity for all operators in our
network but also on the other hand it
helps us to break down costs and to um
you know further disperse the cost of
proving because one large machine could
actually process multip multiple totally
independent smaller proving jobs um you
know further dispersing the operational
costs on the other hand also it may
happen that you need multiple of those
large capacity machines even to complete
certain jobs for example Ethereum block
proving and when you want to bring it
down to uh like Ethereum's block time
you need maybe 50 or 100 GPU nodes at
minimum to be able to get to that level
So I think the approaches are different
There will definitely be uh networks
there I think Nexus um recently had a
couple of test nets where they were
actually exploring people contributing
through browserbased proving and that's
an interesting story obviously the
architecture for that and how they
orchestrate workloads you know breaking
a larger workloads into tiny chunks Yeah
you have networking overhead there and
then aggregating all those tiny proofs
generated in a browser or on different
machines um to come to the final single
proof I think that's um that's a
different challenge So basically the
different approaches have their own
architecture challenges and their own
viability I think
I want to kind of continue on that like
reframing of what the prover network or
prover marketplace like the role that it
plays because the one I des like what I
described kind of at the start was this
idea of this prover network which had a
bunch of like you called them prover
node operators So different teams maybe
with a
standardized prover capacity all running
these nodes and making proofs and then I
always pictured that like the prover
network would be servicing like multiple
networks like multiple L2s for example
multiple proof
requesters but we've seen a lot of the
prover networks come online or like at
least be proposed with like one proof
requesttor customer in mind sometimes
from the same company So you'd have like
I'm a ZKVM I'm creating lots of proofs
I'm also going to run a prover network
where other people can help satisfy
those proofs create those proofs for
this proof requester which is me And so
there's almost like this link between
those two things This was something that
I felt we heard a lot last year Would
you say teams are moving away from that
or moving towards that like how is that
relationship changing and how does how
is actually like ZK cloud maybe a little
bit different from that that's a very
good observation and it is indeed true
that most of the prover networks like
yeah if we step back maybe 18 months it
was autumn 2023 I think um that's when
the initial architecture design of of
glo was released and basically largely
it kicked off kind of like this proveret
craze where early 2024 different teams
started um coming in and announcing
they're building a proof market or a
prover network I think in March yeah it
was March last year when uh we deployed
our first version of the network
Basically this wasn't a scalable network
but it already allowed universal proving
And by universal proving I mean is that
anyone could come in and deploy their
own prover program on the network and
have proofs generated Currently I mean
this is just a side track but if I may
uh mention that currently universal
proving is used for you know teams
supporting different provers and
whatever they integrate proofs can be
generated on their networks for those In
our case universal even goes a bit
further because we allow you we don't
just support any proof system from our
perspective but we allow anyone to bring
their own prover program deploy it and
generate proof So that's very unique in
that sense But coming back to the
initial topic sorry I don't want to
distract too much Coming back to the
initial topic I think it's a very
interesting observation So many of the
teams that had some kind of product like
log ranch uh their co-processor
initially or succinct was building the
the zkvm or risk zero zkvm
um all of them started to offer proving
services for risk zero it was bonsai
which was basically a centralized
service they've provided but then others
started um announcing different poor
networks and I think it's a very viable
thing that they want to you know and
it's a very natural thing that they want
to service those people who come in with
demand uh that they want proof generated
on those CKVMs or on those products Now
some of these teams were actually
planning to go more universal and open
up proving and support other ZKVMs or
ZKVMs potentially
Uh but I also know of a couple who
actually decided to go more focused and
optimized for what they what their own
product is So it's kind of like uh I
think we've got the proven networks that
have been launched by teams that have
some kind of product and they may be a
little more focused on satisfying the
proof demand for that And then you've
got some more universal uh networks
supporting all different ZKVMs and ZKV
EVMs out there I think with Kevlot and
ZK cloud we went even one step further
um where we just offered anyone to
package and deploy their own program
easily and then just start generating
proofs on our network So it's basically
just as simple as referencing the prover
ID that they deployed on the network
sending the inputs defining the the
amount of hardware to be allocated to
that particular job and then off it goes
Um once the the proof has been generated
they can they can fetch the proof So
it's even one step further and I think
that's a that's a key differentiator
there But yeah the dynamics are
interesting on how uh how the different
prover networks have been evolving and
also I think the
marketplaces seem to be interesting
because marketplaces are in my head a
marketplace you know it includes the
word market so it's naturally an
auctionbased platform
Basically everyone puts up an offer for
how expensive a proof would be and then
the proof requesttor can choose Yes
exactly So it's a very good point you
bring up and I think it's very
interesting how also the the different
workload we call these workload
allocation mechanisms work and I think
that's also an interesting topic Maybe
we could touch up on that later Uh proof
mining which is a little bit similar to
to Bitcoin mining where you've got a
race everybody's racing for the job and
whoever generates the proof first gets
rewarded However this is never going to
be the cheapest option because you know
someone has to pay for all that uh
redundant and I could even say wasted
computation involved in the process
Then there are order book based
mechanisms where there are basically
bids and asks How much do proof
providers ask for generating a certain
proof and how much proof requesters are
willing to pay for a certain proof and
when there is a match then uh the
workload is allocated and then uh the
proving job can start Obviously there
can be situations where there is no
match for certain amount of time and for
fairly time constrained workloads that's
not necessarily the best option Then
you've got these different auction
mechanisms uh where it could be a simple
reverse auction where basically there is
a proving job that you want to have
proven and uh you accept bids from
operators or from different prover
networks with a quote for how much they
are willing to actually generate that
proof And usually the the proving since
it's a compute heavy task and it's not a
cheap task to be performed it's very
costsensitive and actually that was one
of the key reasons to start developing
Gavlot back then So the founders of
Gavlot wanted to have one a very cheap
proof provider an order of magnitude
cheaper than the traditional web to
cloud compute providers Plus they wanted
to have a decentralized alternative
because we've seen what happened in web
2 with the the comput space There are
very few large providers that dominate
the space and this is something that um
since we are in the blockchain space we
have this ethos of decentralization and
all the benefits and and advantages that
come with it landing with um the same
centralized setup uh in terms of you
know compute heavy tasks would not be an
optimal scenario at all So that's why
building a decentralized network that is
also providing super cheap proofs for
any user because we've seen that um the
cost of proving it did not make projects
economically viable for quite some time
and as soon as we see that we hit maybe
an order of magnitude drop in in proving
costs those projects and you know
implementing ZK in those projects
actually becomes realistic and you know
it's not a bottleneck anymore more and
then there is randomness coming back to
the workload allocation mechanisms and
and this is how you guys do it right
yeah that's how that's our the decision
that we have made we've seen what
happened with the snark marketplace also
we know that um like we've analyzed a
bunch of different um auction mechanisms
starting from a very simple reverse
Dutch auction to more complex mechanisms
unfortunately whatever sophisticated
architecture you manage to figure out 80
90% of the allocation still depends on
the cost of proving and so that's a
dominant factor and until we are not
able to solve that auctions are very
easily gameable meaning any large entity
uh with a lot of resources could come in
and just under bid everyone else and
make it unprofitable for them and
basically run them out of the market and
then be able to put their prices up Yeah
exactly So an auction and that that's a
very key point I think an auction can be
a way to find you know to let the market
find uh the cheapest cost for uh proving
but as soon as it's gamed and some
dominant entities emerge they can
actually introduce unhealthy economic
dynamics and start influencing the cost
of proving a lot Obviously go to market
is much easier if you let the market
decide the cost of proving because you
don't need to build and figure out the
entire economics yourself We've taken a
very different approach So we wanted to
be very independent in terms of uh any
underlying economics That's why we went
with a very minimal Cosmos-based L1 that
is managing our workload allocation and
the economics And basically this way we
had a clean slate We don't depend on the
economics of Ethereum or an L2 or any
other network that we would be building
on top of So with this L1 we've designed
the economics in a way that it makes
sense for node operators and it ensures
profitability but then it provides super
cheap proving for all the users And um
with randomness the extra benefit that
you get is you can introduce actually
backup mechanisms and fallback
mechanisms into your protocol While with
an auction for example if I win the
auction and I don't deliver the proof
then you need to start the auction
process all over So it's it's very hard
to build by default these fallback
mechanisms or you know backup mechanisms
because you just need to start it all
over It's a onetoone match one
requesttor matched to one proof provider
But with with our network and the the
with randomness being used for workload
allocation we can actually initially
select more than one prover kind of
secondary or you know third provers
backup provers to come in and then we
can also as as a last resort open up the
proving job for anyone to come in from
the network First come first serve
Whoever delivers the proof first uh they
will get rewarded So in a sense there
are multiple layers of execution
guarantees that can easily be built on
top of this architecture that we've
designed So I think longterm this is the
the safe solution for L2s or you know
for proving jobs where actually the
finality of the chain or the progress of
the chain depends on those proofs
arriving So where livveness is the most
important Yes Exactly This is
interesting And so I mean you've defined
these different kind of economic
approaches the proof mining speed the
order book the auction the random You
are identifying the random one as this
is potentially an ideal case for
livveness if it's very critical that
like you can't have a case where the
proofs don't come in or there isn't
relevant party ready or they're down or
something like you need the
redundancy But are there other cases
where an auction is makes more sense or
where an order book or a proof like sort
of proof mining uh model makes more
sense i'd say the mining um wouldn't it
be cheap for the end user no I I think
actually it would be more expensive
because okay with with mining and with
all those parties racing and only one
getting rewarded they would expect those
rewards to be higher and at the end of
the day the it would be the user who is
paying you know um those those higher
fees So I think okay that would land
with with a quite high uh proving cost
Auctions are a good way um to let the
market find the optimal cost and maybe
it can you know be a good tool to find
kind of low proving cost as well On the
other hand we like our bet is that as
soon as you can design an economic model
that is cheap enough you can uh just
bake it into a protocol which ensures
that nobody can actually influence the
cost of proving over time So you bake it
into the protocol and you can just do a
credibly neutral selection through
through randomness basically I think
overall I do believe that randomness
would be the the right long-term
approach even though parties are not
necessarily rational So let's say you've
just you just have a cluster of GPUs for
example and you want like in a rational
world you would want your operational
costs to be covered plus earn something
but very interesting thing is uh and
this is what I heard about alo proving
for example when Alo was on testn net
actually many different operators were
doing proving even though they were only
partially compensated for their
operational costs So the market is not
necessarily or or the operators are not
necessarily rational in that sense What
we have been focusing on is to build a
network that is suitable and optimal for
maybe 98% of the use cases M and for
that uh we bake into the protocol you
know the the characteristics of
decentralization and permissionlessness
all the high livveness sensor resistance
etc that comes with it and uh by
designing user focused economics we
ensure that they get cheap proofs so I
think that's a more long-term approach
rather than a quick go to market and
